div.p: Greetings. I can add nothing now to what I wrote yesterday through your chief scribe.
In the meantime, I received your letters sent through Tumisius.
Their case was heard today, but nothing has been decided yet. The witnesses will be heard tomorrow.
I fear that the young man may have committed himself too eloquently. However, nothing will be done except what is fair and just, and what our laws can support.
You will hear the outcome from them.
I am sending these letters through them, which were handed to me by Ludwig Zehender and Frisching; I could not send them through safer messengers.
If you receive anything more in the meantime, I wish to know. Farewell.
All our friends greet you, especially your and my Zehenders. Bern, August 2, 1560. I will depart for Lausanne next Monday or Tuesday.
Your Johannes Haller from the heart.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church in Zürich, my honorable lord and dearest compatriot. Mr. Heinrich Bullinger in Zürich.
